p: According to the Canonical Correspondence Analysis (CCA), the only significant habitat factors are the content of floatable parts ( p = 0.001) and the content of phosphorus ( p = 0.001). Higher values of these factors are associated with the wetland plots on clay material and to some degree with the forest plots ( Figure 2B). On these sites, there were differences in the frequency of mature trees and saplings (G = 9.858, p = 0.01981, and G = 11.366, p = 0.009904), respectively, whereas the differences in the frequency of the seedlings of R. pseudoacacia among the habitats were not significant (G = 2.7291, p = 0.4353). There were no significant differences in the cover abundance. Only a few individuals of Black locust were found in the WT and the ST habitats ( Figure 2C).
